content.description: Start seated on the smaller hands. Follow jugs to the top. Beware, some of the rock quality seems suspect.
content.location: Immediately right of Easy On Backside Of Burma (V1).

content.description: Use underclings to move into better holds at the top.
content.location: Located in a separate pit next to "Like Shaking Hands with God"

content.description: Stand start with good jug and dead-point(dyno) to the lip.
content.location: Just past the Sloper Problem on the far side of Burma.

content.description: Traverse Right to Left, start with left on a crimp and right on a sloper. Mostly sharp crimps until you get to a three finger pocket and then top out. I don't know if this is an established line.
content.location: Located on the other side of "Head Over Heels".

content.description: Start right of Pinball Arete in the horizontal seam, with your right hand in a pod hold and left on a slimper next to it.  Climb leftwards through a technical and powerful sequence and finish up Pinball Arete.
content.location: Next to pinball arete, in the corridor near the Burmese Python Boulder and Baby Crane.

content.description: Begin on any set of big jugs around the arete 15' left of Classic Warm Up.  Traverse around the corner avoiding putting your feet on the big ramp below the overhang.  Move into soap dish on face and match there.  A long stretch into Classic Warm Up and an easy traverse from there to the Arete Right of Warm Up.  Top out on face to the right of the arete.
Left hand side pull start, Right hand low flatish hold.  Tricky and balancey climbing up the slightly overhanging face with some weird, and kinda sharp holds.  Great moves, technical and sustained.
content.location: Thin Face just left of Pin Ball arete.  Or walk under Shaking hands with god and it will be on the left.

content.description: Climbs the arete left of sloper problem. Starts on sidepull crimps with a huge ledge for feet.
content.location: On the arete to climber's left of sloper problem.

content.description: Slopey
content.location: Left side of Burma Bouldering. Climb the face.

content.description: Short problem.
content.location: Short rock to the left of Warm Up.  Going left is easier, and right a tad harder.  A safe first climb of the day.

content.description: Sit start on low rail, move up and left to topout.  We started right hand underclinging and left on rail but it goes without the undercling too.
content.location: In an elevated cave about 10 feet left of Like Shaking Hands with God.

content.description: Murder Slab variation. Using the right arete at the bottom, climb your way up and into Murder Slab.
content.location: Right of Classic Warm-up and Hard Arete. Can't miss it.

content.description: Slab, tricky start.
content.location: Middle of Burma Boulders.

content.description: Start seated on the good, sharp hold. Make a move to a decent hold before reaching a good horn at the lip and topping out.
content.location: On the short face left of Easy Street (V0).

content.description: Stand start on really small holds and use the obvious good foot. Move up to tiny crimp on the right and reach for the top.
content.location: 5 feet to the right of V-Dyno. Small Arete just past the Sloper Problem.

climbs.name: Purple Gold
climbs.fa: Ian CB or someone else.. anybody know?  Like really know?  I've heard rumors

content.description: Start from a stand with your left hand on the arete and right on an undercling that will pinch you if not grabbed just right.  Pull on and climb up through the center of the wall through edges, a sidepull and big moves.  An easy mantle gets you on top.  A real gem I think, and surely one of the best of the grade in park.  Wait for a dry day, this thing can be wet sometimes.
content.protection: I had four pads.  I put 2 on the slab and two on the bottom.  The slab never came into play.
content.location: Just above the Burmese Python/Shaking hands boulder in the pit.

content.description: Climb the face with the pocket, just left of Classic Warmup.
content.location: 5 feet left of Classic Warmup

content.description: Stand start in crack system and move.... up.
content.location: Obvious crack located across "The Pit" from Pinball Arete. On the backside of The Scoop.

content.description: Climb the arete just right of Tick Tock in the middle of the pit to a spicy topout.  Start standing on the boulder and go straight up the arete.
content.location: Located in "the pit" at Burma.  Near the right side of the cliff line, duck under a wedged, hanging boulder and the problem should be obvious.

content.description: Sit start with an obvious horizontal hold to the right and a low side pull on the left arête. Climb straight up.
content.protection: Fairly low ball, it could be climbed with one pad but there is the butt end of a fallen tree right in the start/landing so a couple more could be helpful.
content.location: Prow-ish feature left of "Easy on Backside of Burma"

content.description: Start just to the left of Shaking hands with God.  Climb completely under the roof using the jam crack.  Interesting and unique movement will see you out of the crack (don't lose your foot in the process). Exit up and to the right.
content.location: Roof crack behind Burmese Python.

content.description: Crux is pulling up to the slab.
content.location: Climb straight up the slab.

content.description: This is an intimidating, awesome line I forgot to add a while back.  From a stand on the ledge, climb the thin vertical face right of hard arête.  A good one to have many pads at your disposal.
content.location: Tall face just right of the classic Hard Arête.

content.description: Start low and left at a block jug feature around chest height! Left hand up to hold on arete and bust a move out right to a side pull/rail feature. Work out the feature to top out boulder. Beware of top out its not bad but the you have the potential to fall in the pit on the backside of the boulder far out of reach of pads and spotters!
content.location: The entrance to the pit?

content.description: Start in juggy slots or matched on the left one.  Gain a good sidepull in a crack right, move through gaston and a sidepull then finish through slopers and finally a jug.  A good sustained line and a nice addition to the Burma circuit.  People should get on this thing.
content.location: Locate Banana Spit.  If looking at that this is straight right 20/30 feet in a hidden corridor.  It is a very obvious line.

content.description: From a sit with a right under king and a left side pull, climb up with balance and slopers to finish.
content.location: Just left around the corner of The Nose.

content.description: Great climb. Start on large rail and move out to left arete. Make some fun heals hook and slaps to gain your way to the top.
content.location: First route you will see when entering Burma.

content.description: Good jug haul warm up. Very unlike DL bouldering.
content.location: Obvious line.

content.description: Hard face.
content.location: Face right of off width.

content.description: Face route.
content.location: Left of "The Scoop".

content.description: Lieback and jam your way up the finger crack in the dihedral. Located around the right corner of Enigma. Don't fall up top or you'll bounce down the laundry chute. Difficulty may depend on finger size.
content.location: In The Pit. To the right of Enigma.

content.description: Project?
content.location: Under this boulder is the entrance to "The Pit".

content.description: Stand start on crack system that works it way up the middle of the face.
content.location: Second problem you see when entering Burma Road. Just to the left of Head over Heels.

content.description: A sweet and pretty line..Start standing in the pit off a couple pads, right hand on the arete, left on a thumbdercling pinch.  Climb the tall face encountering crimpy knobs up high.  The shorter may have to stack an extra pad to start.  A blubber or thin pad is nice to cover the rocky ridge to the right.
content.location: In the pit, just to the right of Purple Gold.

content.description: Stand start on easy arete to the left of Entrance Slab.
content.location: Third problem when entering Burma Road. 6 feet left of easy slab.

content.description: Easy.
content.location: Backside of Burma, past sloper problem. Last problem to the south.

content.description: Start seated with a left hand on an undercling in the arete and right hand on the vertical slot. Make a long move to a pocket. Set up on the face and launch to the lip on poor feet.
content.location: Immediately left of Unknown Crimpy Traverse (V0).

content.description: Start sitting, right hand with an undercling and left on the arete.  Climb the arete to a tricky, and tricky to avoid dabbing mantle.  A little heads up actually.
content.location: Next to Shaking Hands With God.

content.description: Start low on jug and move out to crack in arete.  Fun problem.
content.location: Corner of boulder just before the Sloper Problem.

content.description: Eliminate/contrivance Alert.   We did this and it’s fun so sharing it here. Sit with jug.  Large ledge left is off, and any holds right of the arete are off, along with for feet to right of the arete/crack. Makes perfect sense right? So there ya go, do with it what you will.  There is a really cool pinch hold on this.
content.location: Back of Burma on wall right of Sloper Problem.

content.description: Sit start on obvious shelf and move into good undercling on the bottom of the bulge. Move your feet across the ledge and topout using slopey holds.
content.location: Obvious bulge of rock about 30 feet south of first rock outcropping before coming to The Scoop and Banana Split.

content.description: Big juggy moves with small smeary feet. One sketch section up top but I'll leave that for you to figure out!
content.location: Walk the trail probably 200 feet past Baby Crane and it will be on your right. Obvious, tall, flat landing.

content.description: Starts on 2 crimps way down in the roof under Shaking Hands with God and climbs into that line.  Wild upside down climbing with some really neat holds.  Pumpy.
content.protection: At least a few pads.  The landing is not great.  4 would be good.

content.description: This is the arete just left of Banana Split.  Start low with your left hand on the arete (If your hand touches the boulder next to it, it's not on), and your right on a low 3 finger gaston.  Pull a subtle and hard first move, then continue up the arete.
content.protection: 2-3 pads, the landing has some rocks
content.location: Pretty early on on the right as you walk into Burma, the same boulder as Baby Crane and Banana Split.

content.description: Start with left hand on good sidepull and left hand pushing on the arete to get off the ground. The crux is pulling on the far right hold to get in position for a big move to gain the top.
content.location: Arete to the left of The Scoop.

content.description: Sit start left hand low in crack, right around the arete. Gain left arete and do a couple cool moves to a chill topout. Definitely fun!
content.location: Before 'like shaking hands with god' in hallway on the right

content.description: Climb out the cave and topout on Like Shaking Hands with God.  Start left hand on a crimp and right hand on a good sloper pinch.  Super fun movement and friendly holds.  Very steep and pretty pumpy.  This is a shorter version of Burmese Python and cuts off a few moves.
content.protection: 3 to 4 pads.  Landing is not perfect.

content.description: Fun
content.location: Arete right of Warm Up.

content.description: Sit start with ledge for hands.  Do a funky mantle and climb the short face.
content.location: Face to the right of a sloper problem on the backside of Burma.

content.description: B Side or a Rarity?  You make the call.  Definitely one or the other. Start with a low undercling for the right hand and a biter pinch on the arete for the left.  Establish and likely jump to the lip and mantle out through the hole.
content.protection: 2 pads.  Pad the rock that your back may hit.
content.location: Next to Burmese Python.  Most people scramble up this when with adjacent boulders when going to the popular problem Purple Gold.

content.description:
The Burma Road Bouldering area feels a bit like the Reserve.  There are plenty of good, classic lines, it’s a short approach and there are just as many climbs as the Reserve.  On top of that the quartzite melds with sandstone in spots, which is great and unique. 

 These boulders, however, offer a good chance for a quick workout as the approach is simple and the landings are generally good.
